sect1.title: 138 Reagents, Stains, and Media: Parasitology
sect1.para: IDZI POTTERS AND ANDREA J. LINSCOTT

The evaluation of clinical specimens for ova and parasites in the clinical laboratory can involve the use of direct macroscopic examination of the specimen and microscopic examination of fresh and fixed specimens, as well as culture for some parasitic organisms. These examinations necessitate the use of a variety of stains, reagents, and media, the most common of which are discussed in this chapter.

Because many parasitic organisms cannot be cultured, microscopic examination is the mainstay of diagnostic parasitology. While other test methods, such as multiplex PCR and antigen assays, are also available to detect certain parasites, these methods are limited by the fact that at best, they target only a limited set of parasites. In addition, many laboratories may not have the resources to afford the more expensive molecular assays and needed equipment and infrastructure. Examination after proficient staining of fresh and unconcentrated specimens, as well as fixed and/or concentrated specimens together with permanent stained preparations, most often provides a rapid and accurate diagnosis. A variety of reagents and stains are available for these purposes, and each laboratory must decide which ones to use to best serve its patient population. In addition, because most specimens are submitted in fixatives, the reader should note the specific interference of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and mercury reagents with immunoassays that are commonly used for parasitic diagnosis. As immunoassays and nucleic acid amplification assays become more commonly used for the detection of parasites, reagents needed to perform these tests must be considered, e.g., to avoid problems with inhibition.

Caution should be taken when reagents are used in the parasitology laboratory. Many routinely used compounds can be dangerous if not handled appropriately. For example, formalin and formaldehyde solutions can cause severe skin irritation and, if swallowed, can cause violent vomiting and diarrhea; mercury compounds are local irritants and systemic poisons that can be absorbed through the skin; phenol is a skin irritant, and exposure to large amounts can affect the central nervous system; and xylene can cause serious skin irritation, with extended exposure causing gastrointestinal, neurologic, and tissue damage (1). It is also important to remember that reagents that contain formalin and/or mercury require special disposal. Proper disposal should be carried out using state and federal regulatory guidelines.

sect2.title: REAGENTS
sect2.para: “Fixative” and “preservative” are terms that are often used interchangeably, although these substances serve different purposes. A fixative is a chemical used to penetrate parasitic trophozoites, cysts, and larval forms to halt degeneration or autolysis once the specimen is obtained. It “fixes” the organisms by precipitating or cross-linking proteins. Many commonly used fixatives, such as formalin and other aldehydes, also make the specimen more susceptible to staining. In general, the period in which the specimen is in contact with the fixative should be limited to what is necessary for obtaining optimal morphology. Prolonged exposure should be avoided, since many fixatives will have a detrimental effect on the specimen over time. In contrast to fixatives, preservatives are used for specimen storage, preventing parasite degradation as well as bacterial and fungal overgrowth, while maintaining parasite morphology. Ethanol is a commonly used preservative. Of note, ethanol and methanol are also considered by some to act as fixatives, as they alter the parasite protein structure to prevent degeneration. When ethanol and methanol are paired in a solution, the solution may provide both preservative and fixative functions, though there is some debate as to whether these solutions are true fixatives in the traditional sense. To avoid confusion and provide consistency, the term “fixative” here refers to any of the aforementioned solutions for the purpose of stool transport and collection for parasitology.

Table 1 lists several types of fixatives along with their contents, specific permanent stained smears that can be performed, immunoassays for which they can be used, and additional comments concerning the product. Today, most clinical laboratories purchase premixed, packaged vials of fixatives/adhesives that can be either inoculated with fecal sample sent to the laboratory or sent home with the patient for home collection. A list of commercially available transport vials can be found in Table 2.

Testing for Entamoeba histolytica and/or the E. histolytica/E. dispar group still requires fresh or frozen specimens. Also, for various multiplex molecular tests, very specific collection media may be required (e.g., Cary-Blair or ethanol-based fixatives).

sect1.title: ■ Formalin
sect1.para: Formalin has been used in parasitology as an all-purpose fixative for concentration procedures. However, formalin should not be used to prepare smears for permanent stains, because the reagent does not adequately fix organism morphology (2). Formalin is easy to prepare and has a long shelf life. It is most routinely used as a fixative for stool and duodenal aspirate specimens. Formalin works well to fix the morphologies of helminth ova and larvae and those of protozoan cysts, oocysts, and spores, although it does not fix protozoan trophozoites well. Although both 5% and 10% solutions of formalin are currently used (5% for the best fixation of protozoan stages and 10% for ova and larvae), the 10% formulation is most widely used in clinical parasitology today. A formalin vial is often paired with a vial containing a fixative such as PVA or Schaudinn’s fixative to ensure that a permanent stained smear can be prepared and read. Formalin (10%) is prepared as indicated below.

sect1.title: ■ Buffered formalin
sect1.para: Formalin buffered with sodium and potassium phosphates can be used to help maintain the morphology of parasites for long-term storage and is used for concentration procedures. To make buffered formalin, mix the following dry ingredients and store in a tightly closed container. Add 0.8 g of this mixture to 1 liter of 10% (or 5%) formalin.

sect1.title: ■ Merthiolate-iodine-formalin
sect1.para: Protozoa and helminth ova and larvae can be distinguished on direct wet mounts after stool and duodenal aspirate specimens are fixed in merthiolate-iodine-formalin (MIF). MIF allows not only fixation but also staining of the organisms. MIF can be used to perform concentration procedures. This method requires that the two stock solutions listed below be combined into a fresh working solution immediately before use. In addition, after specimens have been mixed with MIF, the mixture must be left undisturbed for 24 h before preparation of smears from the bottom layer of the three layers that will form. Parasitological examination of specimens placed in MIF can be performed for several weeks after fixation, making it very useful for field surveys. MIF is also readily available commercially.

sect1.title: ■ Sodium acetate-acetic acid-formalin (SAF)
sect1.para: SAF is very similar to formalin in that it is a liquid fixative and contains no mercury. However, unlike formalin, SAF can be used for both concentration techniques and permanent stained smears. The sediment from the concentration procedure is used for both the wet preparation and the permanent stain. Albumin-coated slides allow better adhesion of the concentrated material to the slide and are recommended for use with SAF. SAF is an acceptable substitute for PVA or Schaudinn’s fixative for permanent smears stained with either trichrome or iron hematoxylin. SAF is available commercially and has a long shelf life, but it can also readily be made in the laboratory by mixing the reagents listed below:

sect1.title: PVA-Containing Fixatives
sect1.para: PVA acts as an adhesive for stool material, allowing the stool to adhere to glass slides. Several modifications are commercially available. The compound accompanying the PVA, specifically, mercuric chloride, zinc sulfate, or cupric sulfate, acts as the fixative and allows fixation of protozoan cysts and trophozoites for use with trichrome or iron hematoxylin stains for permanent smears. All PVA-containing fixatives interfere with immunoassays. PVA is not an appropriate reagent to use for stool specimen concentration, as eggs do not concentrate as well in this solution and morphology characteristics may be distorted when it is used to concentrate the sample. Therefore, PVA should be paired with a reagent vial (formalin, MIF, or SAF) that can be used for concentration purpose.

sect1.title: ■ Hg-PVA
sect1.para: The Hg-PVA fixative uses mercuric chloride as the fixative. Protozoan morphology is best fixed with PVA-incorporating mercury compounds. However, due to the toxic nature of mercury compounds and the difficulty in preparation, most laboratories no longer prefer Hg-PVA.

sect1.title: ■ Zn-PVA
sect1.para: The Zn-PVA fixative uses zinc sulfate in place of mercury as a fixative for protozoans. Specimens treated with Zn-PVA may also be stained with trichrome or iron hematoxylin stains for permanent smears.

sect1.title: ■ Cu-PVA
sect1.para: The Cu-PVA fixative uses cupric sulfate in place of mercury as a fixative for protozoans. Specimens treated with Cu-PVA may also be stained with trichrome or iron hematoxylin stains for permanent smears.

NOTE: Studies have shown that zinc sulfate provides a satisfactory, but not equal, substitute for mercury in the permanent staining procedures and that copper sulfate does not fix morphology equally to mercuric chloride (3, 4).

sect1.title: ■ Schaudinn’s fixative
sect1.para: Schaudinn’s fixative is made of mercuric chloride, distilled water, and 95% ethyl alcohol and gives excellent morphological fixation of protozoan organisms. It is used primarily in the preparation of permanent stained smears for parasitological examination from fresh, nonfixed specimens. Specimens fixed in Schaudinn’s fixative can be used with either trichrome or iron hematoxylin stains. As with Hg-PVA, due to the toxic nature of mercuric compounds and the difficulty of preparing this fixative, Schaudinn’s fixative is not routinely made or used in the clinical microbiology laboratory. In addition, Schaudinn’s fixative is becoming increasingly more difficult to purchase commercially. Many laboratories are opting to use a mercury-free or low-mercury-level single vial that can be used to prepare both a concentration and a preparation for permanent stained smears. See “Nonmercury or low-mercury-level, nonformalin fixatives: single-vial systems” below.

sect1.title: ■ Nonmercury or low-mercury-level, nonformalin fixatives: single-vial systems
sect1.para: Several nonmercury, nonformalin proprietary fixatives are commercially available for both concentration of stool specimens and the preparation of permanently stained smears (Medical Chemical Corporation, Torrance, CA; Meridian Bioscience, Cincinnati, OH; Scientific Device Laboratory, Des Plaines, IL). There is also a low-mercury-level, nonformalin proprietary fixative available that can be used as described above (Alpha-Tec, Vancouver, WA). Another formalin-free single-collection device is AlcorFix, which is used in conjunction with a Mini Parasep solvent-free collection tube for concentration (5). This product is manufactured by Apacor (Berkshire, United Kingdom) and is distributed in the United States by VWR. Important advantages of these systems are that only one vial is needed to prepare both a concentration and a permanent stained smear and that the vials can be discarded along with other biohazardous waste in the laboratory. Acceptability for use in fecal immunoassays varies (check with manufacturers for specific uses). Special stains are also available for use with some of these fixatives.

sect2.title: STAINS
sect2.para: Table 3 lists the stains that are most commonly used to detect and aid in the identification of parasitic organisms. Figures 1 through 7 illustrate staining properties of parasites using the various stains mentioned below. The descriptions of and procedures for stains used in parasitology are listed below as well. A list of commercially available parasitology stains can be found in Table 4.

sect1.title: ■ Iodine (Lugol’s or D’Antoni’s)
sect1.para: A solution of iodine can be used for preparing direct or concentrated wet mounts for parasitological examination. These nonspecific dyes allow the differentiation of parasitic cysts from leukocytes, the former of which retain the iodine and appear light brown. Iodine can easily overstain eggs; thus, a wet prep without iodine should be used to detect eggs. Iodine stains can be purchased commercially for use in routine parasitology. These solutions should be stored in dark containers in a dark environment. D’Antoni’s iodine preparation has the advantage of use without further dilution, whereas Lugol’s iodine must be diluted into a working solution (1:5 dilution in distilled water) before use. Working solutions of both iodine preparations fade with time and should be discarded and replaced when their deep yellow-brown color lightens. Note that the iodine evaporates easily from these solutions, so make sure to tightly close the container with iodine solution after every use. Even from an iodine-stained wet mount, the iodine may evaporate over time. This will cause the deep yellow-brown color of parasitic cysts to fade to pale yellow. In this case, it is best to make a new preparation.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place 1 drop of iodine on a slide; add to this a small amount of fecal specimen and mix until homogeneous. The iodine stains fecal material immediately, and the timing of this step is not important. Place a coverslip on top of the suspension and view under a magnification of ×100. Examine any suspicious material under a ×400 magnification.

sect1.title: Acid-Fast Stains (Modified)
sect1.para: Cryptosporidium spp., Cystoisospora belli, and Cyclospora cayetanensis are parasites that may cause diarrheal disease in humans. These organisms are more easily detected when a modified acid-fast stain is used. The modification to the acid-fast stains is the use of decolorizing agents that are less harsh than those used for staining mycobacteria. The carbol fuchsin and counterstain (e.g., methylene blue or malachite green) reagents used for mycobacteria can be used for staining Cryptosporidium spp. and most coccidian parasites; however, interchanging the decolorizing agents may yield inferior results. In the modified acid-fast Kinyoun staining procedure, a 1% solution of sulfuric acid (1 ml of sulfuric acid in 99 ml of water) is recommended, as opposed to the 3% sulfuric acid solution used in the acid-fast bacillus Kinyoun staining procedure. For the modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining procedure, a 5% sulfuric acid solution (5 ml of concentrated sulfuric acid in 95 ml of distilled water) is used, as opposed to the 3% HCl solution in 95% ethanol that is used in the acid-fast bacillus Ziehl-Neelsen staining procedure.

sect1.title: ■ Basic procedure: modified Kinyoun stain (cold method)
sect1.para: Apply specimen (1 or 2 drops) to a slide, allow it to air dry, and fix with absolute methanol for 1 min. Apply carbol fuchsin to the slide for 5 min, and then rinse the slide with 50% ethanol, followed by a water rinse. Add sulfuric acid (1%) decolorizer for 2 min, and rinse the slide again with water. Add methylene blue for 1 min, and then rinse the slide again with water. Air dry the slide and examine at ×100 to ×1,000 magnification. The modified acid-fast stain, used to stainNocardia, which also uses a lower concentration of sulfuric acid, may be an acceptable alternative.

sect1.title: ■ Basic procedure: modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (hot method)
sect1.para: Apply specimen (1 or 2 drops) to a slide, allow it to air dry, and then dry it on a heating block (70°C) for 5 min. Place the slide on a rack and flood it with carbol fuchsin. With an alcohol lamp or Bunsen burner, gently heat the slide until steam appears. Allow the specimen to stain for 5 min and then rinse. Decolorize with 5% sulfuric acid for 30 s and rinse. Counterstain with methylene blue for 1 min and rinse. The slide is then air dried and examined at ×100 to ×1,000 magnification.

sect1.title: ■ Giemsa and Wright’s stains
sect1.para: Examination of blood films for parasites includes the use of two common stains, the Giemsa stain and Wright’s stain, both derivatives of the original Romanowsky stain. These stains are very similar, differing primarily in that no fixative is included in the Giemsa stain; therefore, thin blood films should be fixed with absolute methanol before staining. Although stock solutions of these stains can be prepared in the laboratory, the procedure is very cumbersome and involves grinding of powdered stain with methanol and/or glycerol with a mortar and pestle, days to weeks of storage with shaking, and removal of supernatant or filtering before use. In addition, it is recommended that the Giemsa stain be prepared fresh each day of use by diluting the stain stock solution with phosphate-buffered water, pH 6.4 to 8.0 depending on its use (6). Alternatively, Giemsa, Wright’s, and Wright-Giemsa stain stock solutions are readily available from commercial suppliers in liquid form and may need only dilution in a buffered solution. Blood films may be stained manually, but many laboratories rely on automated hematologic instruments for staining of thin (not thick) blood films, with acceptable results. These stains allow the detection of blood parasites, including Plasmodium spp., microfilariae, Leishmania spp., Babesia spp., and Trypanosoma spp. Although for many years, Giemsa stain has been the stain of choice, these parasites can also be seen on blood films stained with Wright’s stain, a Wright-Giemsa combination stain, or one of the more rapid stains, such as Diff-Quik (American Scientific Products, McGaw Park, IL), Wright’s Dip Stat stain (Medical Chemical Corp.), or Field’s stain. It is important to note that the higher-pH buffer solutions used with Giemsa stain allow the visualization of erythrocytic stippling; whereas Wright’s stain and the Wright-Giemsa stain use a buffer solution with a lower pH of 6.8, which does not guarantee visualization of this stippling. Erythrocytic stippling, like Schüffner’s granulation, seen in some malaria infections, is best seen using the Giemsa stain at pH of 7.0 or above (7). For visualization of Maurer’s clefts (sometimes seen in infections with Plasmodium falciparum), a Giemsa stain at pH 7.2 to 7.6 is preferred (8).
The phosphate buffered solutions are commercially available but can easily be prepared in the lab as well.

sect1.title: Sörensen’s phosphate buffered stock solution
sect1.para: KH2PO4 9,078 g/l in distilled water (solution A)
Na2HPO4·2H2O....11,876 g/l in distilled water (solution B)
Both stock solutions can be kept for 1 month at 4°C in dark, glass bottles.

sect1.title: Sörensen’s phosphate buffered working solution
sect1.para: Depending on the desired pH, mix volumes of solution A and solution B in 900 ml of distilled water.
The phosphate buffer solutions of pH 6.4, 6.8, and 7.2 can also be made using buffer tablets (“Buffer tablets for preparing buffer solution according to Weise”—available from VWR).

Most important, however, is to use a stain with which you are familiar, rather than switching to Giemsa stain, which is somewhat more complicated to use. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes can be used to assess the quality of any of the mentioned blood stains. Any parasites, if present, will stain comparably to the polymorphonuclear leukocytes, regardless of the stain used.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Prepare a 3.5% dilution of commercially available Giemsa stock solution by adding 5 drops of Giemsa stock solution to every 4 ml of the chosen buffer solution. Flood the slide with the diluted Giemsa solution and allow to stain for 20 min. Rinse gently with buffered water or with clean tap water. Allow the slide to air dry and examine it at ×1,000 magnification. Thin blood films should be fixed with methanol in advance to prevent hemolysis during the staining procedure. Other procedures exist for the Giemsa stain, using different concentrations of the staining solution and different staining times, each with satisfactory results. Most important is that laboratory staff are well acquainted with the procedure being used.

The Giemsa stain can be modified slightly, by adding Triton X-100 to the buffer solution. This will improve staining quality and reduce parasite transfer from one slide to another during mass staining (9). The ideal final concentrations of Triton X-100 in the Giemsa working solutions are 0.01% for thin blood films and 0.1% for thick blood films.

Certain hemorrhagic fever viruses, like Ebola virus, may survive for 48 h on a dried blood film. To inactivate these viruses, thin blood films should be fixed for at least 15 min in pure methanol, prior to staining. Thick blood films can be stained for 45 to 60 min, using a 0.25% final concentration of Triton X-100 to inactivate hemorrhagic fever viruses (10).

The following characteristics are seen when smears are stained properly with Giemsa stain, although colors may vary according to the pH used: erythrocytes are pale red or tan and may have a blueish gray tinge, the nuclei of the leukocytes are purple with pale purple cytoplasm, eosinophilic granules are bright purple-red, and neutrophilic granules stain deep pink-purple. When Wright’s stain is used, peripheral blood smears have the following characteristics: erythrocytes stain reddish or buff to bright pink, the nuclei of leukocytes are bright blue with contrasting lighter cytoplasm, eosinophilic granules stain bright red, and neutrophilic granules stain pink or light purple.

For staining of microfilariae, the Giemsa stain can be modified, yielding better results, by doubling the concentration of the stain and doubling the staining time. This modified Giemsa stain is best performed at pH 8.0, but note that it still does not reliably stain the sheath of certain microfilaria species. For more reliably staining the sheath of microfilariae, hematoxylin stains should be used (see “Hematoxylin stains” below).

sect1.title: ■ Field’s stain for blood
sect1.para: Field’s stain is yet another version of the Romanowsky stain and is used for staining of thick blood films for the detection of malaria. It has the advantage of being a very fast staining technique, as staining times are limited to only a few seconds. This staining uses two different staining solutions, Field’s stain A and Field’s stain B, which can both be bought commercially in powder form. For each of the staining solutions, 25 g of the corresponding powder is added to 80 ml of distilled water, mixed thoroughly, and filtered before use. The staining solutions should be replaced after 1 month.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place the thick blood film in Field’s staining solution A for 5 s; then gently rinse with tap water. Subsequently stain with Field’s staining solution B for 3 s; then rinse again with tap water. Allow the slide to air dry in an upright position and examine it at ×1,000 magnification.

A modification of the Field’s stain exists (see “Other stains” below) that allows the detection ofAcanthamoeba spp. This modified Field’s stain uses methanolic eosin instead of buffered eosin in the B staining solution.

sect1.title: ■ Delafield’s hematoxylin stain
sect1.para: Delafield’s hematoxylin stain is used for thin and concentrated blood films for the detection of microfilariae and may show greater detail of the nuclei and sheaths than Giemsa and Wright’s stains. Although the stain is not procedurally difficult to prepare, it does involve an aging process of 1 week followed by 1 month before it can be used. Delafield’s hematoxylin stain is not readily available commercially and is used only under special circumstances. Preparation of the stain involves dissolving 180 g of aluminum ammonium sulfate in 1 liter of distilled water, heating until dissolved, and cooling (ammonium alum). Hematoxylin crystals (4 g) are dissolved in 25 ml of 95% ethyl alcohol, and the solution is then added to 400 ml of the ammonium alum. The solution is then covered with a cotton plug and exposed to sunlight and air for 1 week, after which it is filtered. To this solution, 100 ml each of glycerol and 95% ethyl alcohol is added. This solution is placed in sunlight for at least 1 month (11). There is one paper reporting that the hematoxylin-eosin stain used in cytology was able to stain microfilaria and their sheath (12).

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Allow the specimen on a slide to air dry. Lake blood films with distilled water for 15 min and fix in absolute methanol for 5 min, followed by air drying. Stain for 10 to 15 min and rinse in water. Air dry, add a coverslip with mounting fluid, and examine the slide at ×100 to ×400 (or ×1,000) magnification.

sect1.title: ■ Carazzi’s hematoxylin stain
sect1.para: As an alternative to Delafield’s hematoxylin stain, Carazzi’s hematoxylin stain can be used for the detection of microfilariae. This staining will also show improved detail of nuclei and sheaths compared to Giemsa and Wright’s stain. An important advantage is that the staining solution is easier to prepare and is even commercially available. The stain is prepared by thoroughly mixing 800 ml of (preferably carbonate-free) demineralized water and 200 ml of glycerol. While stirring well, slowly dissolve 50 g of potassium alum in the mixture. Add 0.4 g of sodium iodate and dissolve. Finally, dissolve 2.0 g of hematoxylin and stir well. The solution can be kept for 6 months in a tightly closed brown glass bottle at room temperature.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place prepared slides in methanol for 3 min (not needed for thick blood films). Shake off the methanol and allow to air dry. Place the slides overnight in a Coplin jar with Carazzi’s stain. Gently rinse the slides with clean tap water. Allow the slides to air dry, add a coverslip with mounting fluid, and examine at ×100 to ×400 (or ×1,000) magnification.

sect1.title: ■ Iron hematoxylin stain
sect1.para: Iron hematoxylin stains are used for the detection, identification, and enumeration of intestinal protozoan parasites. There are many derivations of the iron hematoxylin stain, all of which can be used with fresh fecal specimens, fixed specimens containing PVA, or specimens fixed in Schaudinn’s fixative or SAF to make permanent stained smears. Depending on the type of sample used, an agent used to improve adhesion to the glass slide may be required. Solutions of hematoxylin-ethanol and ferrous ammonium sulfate-hydrochloric acid are combined in equal parts to make a working iron hematoxylin stain. Both solutions are available commercially.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place prepared slides in 70% ethanol for 5 min. If mercury-based fixatives are being used, place the slide in 70% ethanol with iodine for 5 min and then again in 70% ethanol for 5 min more (the last two steps are not necessary for non-mercury-based fixatives). Wash the slide in running tap water for 10 min and place it in iron hematoxylin working solution for 5 min. After this staining step, wash again in running tap water for 10 min and then place the slide in the following reagents for 5 min each: 70% ethanol, 95% ethanol, 100% ethanol (twice), and xylene (or a substitute) (twice). Add mounting fluid, cover with a coverslip, and allow to dry overnight or for 1 h at 37°C. Examine the slide at ×500 to ×1,000 magnification with an oil immersion lens.

sect1.title: ■ Trichrome stain (Wheatley trichrome stain)
sect1.para: The Wheatley trichrome stain, a modification of the Gomori tissue stain, is used for the detection, identification, and enumeration of intestinal protozoan parasites (13). This stain uses chromotrope 2R and light green SF stains to visually distinguish internal elements of protozoan parasitic cysts and trophozoites. Trichrome staining is usually performed on fecal specimens fixed using PVA or Schaudinn’s fixative. MIF- or SAF-fixed specimens may also be stained with the trichrome stain, as well as specimens fixed with single-vial systems. In addition, some proprietary stains are also available that may work better with these and other fixatives to make permanent stained preparations. Trichrome stain can be easily prepared in the laboratory or purchased from a commercial supplier. It is important to remember that many of the single-vial collection devices require a specific trichrome stain unique to that collection device. For example, the Eco-Fix collection device uses the Para-Pak EcoStain set (Meridian Bioscience), and the PROTO-FIX fixative uses the PROTO-FIX stain (Alpha-Tec Systems).

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place a prepared slide in 70% ethanol for 5 min. For mercury-based fixatives only, place the slide in 70% ethanol with iodine for 1 min or for as long as 10 min (PVA-fixed air-dried specimens). Then place the slide again in 70% ethanol for 5 min (twice). Place in trichrome stain for 10 min, followed by a 1- to 3-s rinse in 90% ethanol with acetic acid. Dip the slide several times in 100% ethanol, and then place it in 100% ethanol for 3 min (twice), followed by xylene for 5 to 10 min (twice). Add mounting fluid, and add a coverslip. Dry overnight or for 1 h at 37°C. Examine at ×500 to ×1,000 magnification with an oil-immersion lens.

If 95% alcohol is used as a substitute for 100% ethanol and xylene substitutes are used, it is important to increase the dehydration times for both the alcohol and xylene substitutes by at least 5 min.

sect1.title: ■ Acid-fast trichrome stain
sect1.para: The acid-fast trichrome staining technique allows the detection of acid-fast coccidia (Cystoisospora belli and Cyclospora cayetanensis) and of Cryptosporidium spp. (14). Smears prepared from fresh or fixed fecal material can be used in this staining procedure.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place a prepared, air-dried slide in absolute methanol for 5 to 10 min and then again allow it to air dry. Place the slide in carbol fuchsin solution for 10 min before rinsing in tap water. Decolorize with 0.5% acetic acid in alcohol and rinse in tap water. Place the slide in trichrome stain for 30 min at 37°C. Rinse the slide in the acetic acid-alcohol solution for 10 s and then dip it several times in 95% alcohol for 10 s. Place the slide in 95% alcohol for 30 s and then allow it to air dry. Examine at ×1,000 magnification.

sect1.title: ■ Negative carbol fuchsin staining according to Heine
sect1.para: This staining technique is used especially to look for oocysts ofCryptosporidium spp., although coccidians can be visualized as well (15, 16). It is a very useful screening technique, as it is fast, uses only one (commercially available) reagent, and can be performed right next to the microscope on fresh, fixed, or even concentrated specimens. If desired, positive slides can be confirmed with and acid-fast staining, thus increasing specificity.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place a small amount of feces (fresh, fixed, or concentrated) on a glass slide. Add an equal amount of carbol fuchsin solution and mix well (for solid feces, add some extra drops of carbol fuchsin solution). Make a thin smear from this mixture. Let the preparation air dry. The smear should be dry within 15 min. Place a drop of immersion oil on the preparation and examine at ×500 to ×1,000 magnification. Alternatively, cover the immersion oil with a coverslip and examine at ×400 magnification.Cryptosporidium oocysts will appear as round, nonstained, highly refractile structures 3 to 6 μm in diameter.

sect1.title: ■ Modified Field’s stain
sect1.para: Modified Field’s stain facilitates the identification ofAcanthamoeba species. This stain was evaluated and shown to give very good contrast compared with other stains, such as Wright’s, Giemsa, Ziehl-Neelsen, and trichrome stains. For information on preparation and use of modified Field’s stain, refer to the article by Pirehma and colleagues (17).

sect1.title: ■ Modified safranin stain
sect1.para: Modified safranin stain allows the detection ofCyclospora and Cryptosporidium oocysts in formalin-fixed specimens and fecal concentrates. The stain most commonly used in the past for these organisms was the modified acid-fast stain; however, tremendous variations in staining properties can be seen with this stain. The modified safranin stain reportedly uniformly stains oocysts of Cyclospora and can also be used for the detection of Cryptosporidium. It has also been shown to be fast, reliable, and easy to perform (18).

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place a prepared thin smear of stool on a 60°C slide warmer until dried. Allow to cool to room temperature. Cover with a 3% HCl solution in pure methanol for 5 min. Rinse the smear with tap water. Cover smear with a 1% safranin solution (in water, pH 6.5) and heat in a microwave oven at 650 W for 30 to 60 s. Rinse the smear with tap water for 30 s, counterstain with 1% aqueous methylene blue for 1 min, rinse with tap water, and air dry. Examine at ×1,000 magnification.

sect1.title: ■ Calcofluor white stain
sect1.para: Calcofluor white, one of a number of optical brighteners, binds to cellulose and chitin and fluoresces best when exposed to long-wavelength UV light. These properties allow its use in detecting, e.g., cysts of free-living amebae likeNaegleria (in culture), Acanthamoeba, and Balamuthia species, as well as the larvae of Dirofilaria species (its cuticle contains chitin). Calcofluor white is available through several commercial suppliers, and the staining solution is also easily made in the laboratory by following the manufacturer’s recommendations.

sect1.title: Basic procedure
sect1.para: Place the specimen on a slide and allow it to air dry. Fix the slide in methanol for 1 to 2 min, rinse with distilled water, and allow it to air dry. Add 1 or 2 drops of 10% KOH, place 1 or 2 drops of calcofluor white solution on the specimen for 3 min, and view the slide with a fluorescent microscope and barrier filter (300 to 412 nm) at ×100 to ×400 magnification.

sect2.title: MEDIA
sect2.para: Cultures can be performed for only a few parasitic organisms, includingAcanthamoeba species, Naegleria fowleri, Plasmodium species, intestinal amebae (like Entamoeba histolytica), Trichomonas vaginalis, Leishmania species, and Trypanosoma species (6). However, most clinical diagnostic microbiology laboratories do not provide parasite cultures. Cultures of these organisms are done only at large reference laboratories or research facilities. The exception is T. vaginalis, for which commercial products have been adapted for the routine laboratory. Many of the media listed in Table 5 are not commercially available but are listed for reference. Culture media used for parasite recovery are sometimes referred to as being either defined or undefined. Defined medium differs from undefined medium in that all ingredients used are listed and exact concentrations of each nutrient is known and also listed. Additional information regarding these media is available in the literature (1, 2, 17, 19–21).
